segment.source: Learn how to define and use custom constraints for speech recognition.
segment.target: Learn how to define and use custom constraints for speech recognition.

segment.target: Define custom recognition constraints

segment.target: Define custom recognition constraints

segment.source: Learn how to define and use custom constraints for speech recognition.
segment.target: Learn how to define and use custom constraints for speech recognition.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: SpeechRecognitionTopicConstraint
segment.target: SpeechRecognitionTopicConstraint

segment.source: SpeechRecognitionListConstraint
segment.target: SpeechRecognitionListConstraint

segment.source: SpeechRecognitionGrammarFileConstraint
segment.target: SpeechRecognitionGrammarFileConstraint

segment.source: Speech recognition requires at least one constraint to define a recognizable vocabulary.
segment.target: Speech recognition requires at least one constraint to define a recognizable vocabulary.

segment.source: If no constraint is specified, the predefined dictation grammar of Universal Windows apps is used.
segment.target: If no constraint is specified, the predefined dictation grammar of Universal Windows apps is used.

segment.source: See Speech recognition.
segment.target: See Speech recognition.

segment.source: Add constraints
segment.target: Add constraints

segment.source: Use the SpeechRecognizer.Constraints property to add constraints to a speech recognizer.
segment.target: Use the SpeechRecognizer.Constraints property to add constraints to a speech recognizer.

segment.source: Here, we cover the three kinds of speech recognition constraints used from within an app.
segment.target: Here, we cover the three kinds of speech recognition constraints used from within an app.

segment.source: (For voice command constraints, see Launch a foreground app with voice commands in Cortana.)
segment.target: (For voice command constraints, see Launch a foreground app with voice commands in Cortana.)

segment.source: SpeechRecognitionTopicConstraint—A constraint based on a predefined grammar (dictation or web search).
segment.target: SpeechRecognitionTopicConstraint—A constraint based on a predefined grammar (dictation or web search).

segment.source: SpeechRecognitionListConstraint—A constraint based on a list of words or phrases.
segment.target: SpeechRecognitionListConstraint—A constraint based on a list of words or phrases.

segment.source: SpeechRecognitionGrammarFileConstraint—A constraint defined in a Speech Recognition Grammar Specification (SRGS) file.
segment.target: SpeechRecognitionGrammarFileConstraint—A constraint defined in a Speech Recognition Grammar Specification (SRGS) file.

segment.source: Each speech recognizer can have one constraint collection.
segment.target: Each speech recognizer can have one constraint collection.

segment.source: Only these combinations of constraints are valid:
segment.target: Only these combinations of constraints are valid:

segment.source: A single-topic constraint, or predefined grammar (dictation or web search).
segment.target: A single-topic constraint, or predefined grammar (dictation or web search).

segment.source: No other constraints are allowed.
segment.target: No other constraints are allowed.

segment.source: A combination of list constraints and/or grammar-file constraints.
segment.target: A combination of list constraints and/or grammar-file constraints.

segment.source: Remember: Call the SpeechRecognizer.CompileConstraintsAsync method to compile the constraints before starting the recognition process.
segment.target: Remember: Call the SpeechRecognizer.CompileConstraintsAsync method to compile the constraints before starting the recognition process.

segment.source: Specify a web-search grammar (SpeechRecognitionTopicConstraint)
segment.target: Specify a web-search grammar (SpeechRecognitionTopicConstraint)

segment.source: Topic constraints (dictation or web-search grammar) must be added to the constraints collection of a speech recognizer.
segment.target: Topic constraints (dictation or web-search grammar) must be added to the constraints collection of a speech recognizer.

segment.source: Here, we add a web-search grammar to the constraints collection.
segment.target: Here, we add a web-search grammar to the constraints collection.

segment.source: Specify a programmatic list constraint (SpeechRecognitionListConstraint)
segment.target: Specify a programmatic list constraint (SpeechRecognitionListConstraint)

segment.source: List constraints must be added to the constraints collection of a speech recognizer.
segment.target: List constraints must be added to the constraints collection of a speech recognizer.

segment.source: Keep the following points in mind:
segment.target: Keep the following points in mind:

segment.source: You can add multiple list constraints to a constraints collection.
segment.target: You can add multiple list constraints to a constraints collection.

segment.source: You can use any collection that implements IIterableString for the string values.
segment.target: You can use any collection that implements IIterableString for the string values.

segment.source: Here, we programmatically specify an array of words as a list constraint and add it to the constraints collection of a speech recognizer.
segment.target: Here, we programmatically specify an array of words as a list constraint and add it to the constraints collection of a speech recognizer.

segment.source: Specify an SRGS grammar constraint (SpeechRecognitionGrammarFileConstraint)
segment.target: Specify an SRGS grammar constraint (SpeechRecognitionGrammarFileConstraint)

segment.source: SRGS grammar files must be added to the constraints collection of a speech recognizer.
segment.target: SRGS grammar files must be added to the constraints collection of a speech recognizer.

segment.source: The SRGS Version 1.0 is the industry-standard markup language for creating XML-format grammars for speech recognition.
segment.target: The SRGS Version 1.0 is the industry-standard markup language for creating XML-format grammars for speech recognition.

segment.source: Although Universal Windows apps provide alternatives to using SRGS for creating speech-recognition grammars, you might find that using SRGS to create grammars produces the best results, particularly for more involved speech recognition scenarios.
segment.target: Although Universal Windows apps provide alternatives to using SRGS for creating speech-recognition grammars, you might find that using SRGS to create grammars produces the best results, particularly for more involved speech recognition scenarios.

segment.source: SRGS grammars provide a full set of features to help you architect complex voice interaction for your apps.
segment.target: SRGS grammars provide a full set of features to help you architect complex voice interaction for your apps.

segment.source: For example, with SRGS grammars you can:
segment.target: For example, with SRGS grammars you can:

segment.source: Specify the order in which words and phrases must be spoken to be recognized.
segment.target: Specify the order in which words and phrases must be spoken to be recognized.

segment.source: Combine words from multiple lists and phrases to be recognized.
segment.target: Combine words from multiple lists and phrases to be recognized.

segment.source: Link to other grammars.
segment.target: Link to other grammars.

segment.source: Assign a weight to an alternative word or phrase to increase or decrease the likelihood that it will be used to match speech input.
segment.target: Assign a weight to an alternative word or phrase to increase or decrease the likelihood that it will be used to match speech input.

segment.source: Include optional words or phrases.
segment.target: Include optional words or phrases.

segment.source: Use special rules that help filter out unspecified or unanticipated input, such as random speech that doesn't match the grammar, or background noise.
segment.target: Use special rules that help filter out unspecified or unanticipated input, such as random speech that doesn't match the grammar, or background noise.

segment.source: Use semantics to define what speech recognition means to your app.
segment.target: Use semantics to define what speech recognition means to your app.

segment.source: Specify pronunciations, either inline in a grammar or via a link to a lexicon.
segment.target: Specify pronunciations, either inline in a grammar or via a link to a lexicon.

segment.source: For more info about SRGS elements and attributes, see the SRGS Grammar XML Reference .
segment.target: For more info about SRGS elements and attributes, see the SRGS Grammar XML Reference .

segment.source: To get started creating an SRGS grammar, see How to Create a Basic XML Grammar.
segment.target: To get started creating an SRGS grammar, see How to Create a Basic XML Grammar.

segment.source: Keep the following points in mind:
segment.target: Keep the following points in mind:

segment.source: You can add multiple grammar-file constraints to a constraints collection.
segment.target: You can add multiple grammar-file constraints to a constraints collection.

segment.source: Use the .grxml file extension for XML-based grammar documents that conform to SRGS rules.
segment.target: Use the .grxml file extension for XML-based grammar documents that conform to SRGS rules.

segment.source: This example uses an SRGS grammar defined in a file named srgs.grxml (described later).
segment.target: This example uses an SRGS grammar defined in a file named srgs.grxml (described later).

segment.source: In the file properties, the Package Action is set to Content with Copy to Output Directory set to Copy always:
segment.target: In the file properties, the Package Action is set to Content with Copy to Output Directory set to Copy always:

segment.source: This SRGS file (srgs.grxml) includes semantic interpretation tags.
segment.target: This SRGS file (srgs.grxml) includes semantic interpretation tags.

segment.source: These tags provide a mechanism for returning grammar match data to your app.
segment.target: These tags provide a mechanism for returning grammar match data to your app.

segment.source: Grammars must conform to the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Semantic Interpretation for Speech Recognition (SISR) 1.0 specification.
segment.target: Grammars must conform to the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Semantic Interpretation for Speech Recognition (SISR) 1.0 specification.

segment.source: Here, we listen for variants of "yes" and "no".
segment.target: Here, we listen for variants of "yes" and "no".

segment.source: Manage constraints
segment.target: Manage constraints

segment.source: After a constraint collection is loaded for recognition, your app can manage which constraints are enabled for recognition operations by setting the IsEnabled property of a constraint to true or false.
segment.target: After a constraint collection is loaded for recognition, your app can manage which constraints are enabled for recognition operations by setting the IsEnabled property of a constraint to true or false.

segment.source: The default setting is true.
segment.target: The default setting is true.

segment.source: It's usually more efficient to load constraints once, enabling and disabling them as needed, rather than to load, unload, and compile constraints for each recognition operation.
segment.target: It's usually more efficient to load constraints once, enabling and disabling them as needed, rather than to load, unload, and compile constraints for each recognition operation.

segment.source: Use the IsEnabled property, as required.
segment.target: Use the IsEnabled property, as required.

segment.source: Restricting the number of constraints serves to limit the amount of data that the speech recognizer needs to search and match against the speech input.
segment.target: Restricting the number of constraints serves to limit the amount of data that the speech recognizer needs to search and match against the speech input.

segment.source: This can improve both the performance and the accuracy of speech recognition.
segment.target: This can improve both the performance and the accuracy of speech recognition.

segment.source: Decide which constraints are enabled based on the phrases that your app can expect in the context of the current recognition operation.
segment.target: Decide which constraints are enabled based on the phrases that your app can expect in the context of the current recognition operation.

segment.source: For example, if the current app context is to display a color, you probably don't need to enable a constraint that recognizes the names of animals.
segment.target: For example, if the current app context is to display a color, you probably don't need to enable a constraint that recognizes the names of animals.

segment.source: To prompt the user for what can be spoken, use the SpeechRecognizerUIOptions.AudiblePrompt and SpeechRecognizerUIOptions.ExampleText properties, which are set by means of the SpeechRecognizer.UIOptions property.
segment.target: To prompt the user for what can be spoken, use the SpeechRecognizerUIOptions.AudiblePrompt and SpeechRecognizerUIOptions.ExampleText properties, which are set by means of the SpeechRecognizer.UIOptions property.

segment.source: Preparing users for what they can say during the recognition operation increases the likelihood that they will speak a phrase that can be matched to an active constraint.
segment.target: Preparing users for what they can say during the recognition operation increases the likelihood that they will speak a phrase that can be matched to an active constraint.
